A brief summary:

There is a 9 point circle (center of a triangle's side midpoints, altitudes of foots, and midpoint of orthocenter) identified in a triangle in which the largest circle that can fit in it whilst not expanding past the boundaries of a triangle is the incircle. The largest circle in which each verticie of the triangle touches is the circumcircle. With this there can be argued a 4th side of a triangle in which follows the same pattern of the other sides having its endpoints at the circumcircle, midpoints on the 9 point circle, and are tangent to the incircle.

I know it's a clickbaity short clip, but shouldn't we say, we found out:
A triangle's X points (that are formed by whatever) make a circle, and those formed by another method yield another circle or whatever, and then there is happened to be a line that matches those criteria?
It's like saying (a circle is a polygon whose circumference is pi*the length of longest line segment that can be inscribed inside it). I doubt anybody would consider a triangle or a rectangle (or any polygon for that matter) that has this attribute to be considered a circle.
P.S., I did some math and I don't think that's possible with regular polygons, (circum < pi*longest side possible). But with polygons that are bent to the inside (angles >= 180) I can imagine having a polygon that is always twisted such that it's not possible to have a line segment greater in length than distance x, but also extending very long that don't have a reason to (circum = pi*longest side possible inscribed within) is met. I'm not a mathematician so forgive that I can't prove or demonstrate that, but you can easily imagine a spiral (as in S shape) where that condition applies.
So just because we found out a circle has that attribute, doesn't mean that anything (a polygon in this case) that meets this criterion will be considered a circle. If my reasoning is fine, I don't think anyone can call an S-shaped polygon a circle.

Incase people are wondering why it is considered a “side”:

After drawing the three circles were only 3 lines that are on them, which all of them are part of a triangle’s side. With this discovery we see that there is actually an exception that also fits, which was only achievable with sides.

Still sides aren’t defined by the unique properties they have so it still isn’t a real side but extremely interesting nevertheless.

TL;DR: it’s not actually a side by definition but also not just “a shape” or “a line” like many comments suggest

Ok, so tell me if I'm wrong but, here's my logic.

noun
1.a position to the left or right of an object, place, or central point.
"a town on the other side of the river"

2.an upright or sloping surface of a structure or object that is not the top or bottom and generally not the front or back.
"a car crashed into the side of the house"

So if a side is to the left or right of a central point of the object, the original three sided triangle has indeed a center point with the sides surrounding it. However after your adjustments, the line actually creates a divide in the original object. After it is spilt into an irregular quadrilateral and a smaller triangle. So the triangle ends up still having three sides but sharing a side with the irregular quadrilateral. This is proven because in splitting it, you made two central points.

Man, I really like most of vsauce's videos, but this one just straight-up uses bad logic.

If side of triangle -> properties (regarding the inscribed, circumscribed, and 3rd circle and the associated lines/midpoints/intersections)
The argument is:
If properties -> side of triangle.

This is not necessarily true! If A implies B, it does not mean B implies A!

It would be correct to say:
If not properties -> not side of triangle.

Though I think this video is just for good fun and not a serious argument, I don't like seeing bad logic :(

So I've been trying to figure this out as someone who isn't great at math but interested in this concept. Here's what I understand so far.
There are 3 circles used to measure the properties of a triangle, or actually, they just happen to line up in this particular triangle in this particular way. The first 2 are the incircle and the outer circle, which are simple to understand. The other circle is called the 9 point circle, and it is connected on 9 different points in this triangle's measurements. Those points are: the 3 points that are half the distance to the triangle's orthocenter, the 3 points that are at the "foot" of each of it's altitudes, and the 3 midpoints of each side, all of those 9 points line up on that third circle. That third circle, as far as I can tell, is unique to this specific triangle's measurements, and allows for a fourth "side" which is basically just a line that is a perfect mimic of the other sides in this triangle. It falls on the same points, and holds all the same measurements. That is why it is considered a POSSIBLE side, but it technically isn't a side because it isn't connected and enclosed in the triangle, also because it simply would make the triangle a different shape if it WERE connected because triangles don't have more than 3 sides, and if the triangle DID have 4 sides, it wouldn't work with all of those measurements, therefore the triangle wouldn't even have that fourth side, so it is an endless loop. But the fourth side can never be a side because it only passes through the triangle in a way that holds the same properties as the other 3 except for the fact that it is passing through rather than creating a shape that isn't just a line on its own. That is the only property it doesn't share, as far as I understand.
To explain what the 9 points are that make that 9 point circle: The orthocenter is the point where the 3 altitudes that stem from each of the vertices to the opposite side, all of those lines meet in that middle. Altitude means the height, it's like where all the heights of the triangle point to. There are more than one altitudes because you can flip the triangle around and call it the "height." So basically, on each of those lines that meet in the orthocenter, you divide those lines in half to get your first 3 points on the 9 point circle. The next 3 points are at the "foot" of each altitude, which is just the place on the side where the vertices land to make the full "height" or altitude. It is like, when you connect the vertices to their opposite sides, that point in the middle of the triangle's side where the line lands, is the foot because it's the ending spot. And then the final 3 points for that triangle come from the 3 midpoints of each side of the triangle which is basically just half of each side. I'm not sure if a 9 point circle can be made for every type of triangle or what it is used for.

I think this is a misrepresentation of what defines a "side". A side in this context is simply the edge of a 2-dimensional shape. If I took a 4"× 2" rectangle and placed the largest perfect circle I could fit within the perimeter of the rectangle smack dab in the center, the circle would not touch either of the 2" edges. No matter where you place the circle in the rectangle, you will always end up with at least one edge out of reach. If that is the case, would the longer edges of said rectangle be considered sides while the shorter ones would not? If BF Sherman couldn't think of any other way describe that line except "the forth side of a triangle" he should have just invented a new term for it. Because unlike the three other sides of this triangle, this side is not tangible. It does not visibly exist within the shape's pure form.

The in-circle, circum-circle, and nine-point circle were ideas created afterwards to find the mid points, end points, etc. They don’t suggest that there can’t be another line, but rather that the points on a triangle can be found by using them. I can run a tape measure from one corner of my house to another. Does that mean I have a fifth, invisible wall that goes diagonally across the room? No. It’s still a four-walled room.

Just because the line meets 3 criteria, that the actual sides of the triangle also meet, doesn't mean it is a fourth side. It just means, it is curiosity, that this line also meets the criteria. The actual sides also need to meet other criteria, that this line doesn't meet: The end points of a side have to connect to the end point of another side. The side line has to border the area inside the triangle (or generalized: the shape) and not cut it. And probably several more, that I can't think about right now.

So, I feel like the term “side” for the new line is a bit far fetched since triangle flat out means three angles. So a triangle would be a closed shape consisting of three angles connected with straight lines. Those are the “sides” of the triangle because it creates the shapes perimeter. This fourth line follows all of the rules that the other three lines follow regarding the circles but it isn’t involved with the perimeter or the shape’s angles or shape. Wouldn’t this fourth “side” be more of an exception to the rules? Especially since that line can be place anywhere along the outside circle as long as it follows the same rules as the three circles.

I think this doesn't prove that a triangle has four sides, but that we have to reconsider what makes a triangle's side segment. Because, this explanation proves that there is a fourth (and if my personal observations are right, there even more than that) segment that touches those said points in the triangle and in the circles around and in it.

So, it doesn't seem like there is an actual fourth "side", rather, a fourth segment that has a lot of the requirements to be a side of a triangle. And what does it lack? Well, if I am correct, the segment's origins points are not the same as any of the triangle sides' origin points. So it isn't a fourth triangle size, it's just really close.

Define side and define triangle...

Side- one of the surfaces forming the OUTSIDE OF or BOUNDING a thing, or one of the lines bounding a geometric figure. either of the two broad surfaces of a thin, flat object, as a door, a piece of paper, etc. one of the lateral surfaces of an object, as opposed to the front, back, top, and bottom.

Triangle - A triangle is a polygon with three EDGES and three vertices.

Edge - In a polygon, an edge is a line segment ON the boundary, and is often called a side.

Boundary - A line or border AROUND the OUTSIDE of a shape. It defines the SPACE or AREA.


Since you say it's a side it must also be a line segment ON a boundary and as boundaries are concern they are AROUND THE OUTSIDE OF A SHAPE. Your extra side doesn't define the Space or Area of the actual triangle itself therefore it's null.

Man, Vsauce content is not only increasing times between uploads in the several years, but the content is getting much lazier and shorter too. There were 15 video uploads in the last year, 12 of those being less than 60 seconds in length. Only 3 videos were traditional, long-form, informative Vsauce content, while the rest of the content didn't have much information, sometimes literally none. 7 out of these 15 uploads were solely ads for products he's selling, with the most recent 8 uploads on the channel containing 6 of those ads and the other two videos just being short clips about farts.



Comparatively, eight years ago, there were 41 videos in the year. During that year, 40 of them were the traditional long-form videos, ranging between 5 - 16 minutes each, none of them being advertisements, each packed with research and clever/fascinating information and explanation. The only outlier was a 5 minute video from his "LÜT" series, which reviews and examines weird and interesting things found on the internet. It was like an entire different channel than today's Vsauce.



I get he's probably busy with new projects that are much more profitable for him and he's already made enough money that he never has to make another video, but it's just sad. Vsauce was known for being one of the best channels on the platform, which inspired people to learn, presenting concepts in science, math, language, philosophy, etc., in an intuitive and creative fashion. Now the channel has been operating as a social media marketing vehicle, with a focus of selling products and keeping engagement up with short clips during the absence of real content.



I don't blame Michael for it, he has to make money for his family, just like everyone. As his focus turns to business ventures, he probably doesn't have the time to make new content. Michael has been doing it a long time too, I'm guessing he doesn't have the same passion for, and isn't excited about creating content that encourages viewers to learn. Still, he has provided YouTube with so much top-tier content, and doesn't owe us anything. It's just a depressing reality, the state of the channel is so much different than it used to be, and all the changes are sad.

Simple but important distinction: You have defined a fourth LINE, not SIDE. You are totally ignoring the fourth lines relationship to the two lines it intersects but the one line it does not. This has implications.
A triangle is defined by three sides which are straight lines, each of which connected to the two other lines at one end point coordinate.
That defines the triangle as a shape. Its geographic coordinates, connected by straight lines, define three SIDES to a geometric shape.
The end points of the fourth line you introduce AFTER defining the shape of the triangle with the original three lines.
Note you can not supplement any of the first three lines with the newly drawn fourth line and retain the structural definition of the shape. Its end points don't connect.
Here the fourth line's end points are totally arbitrary to the definition of the structure/shape, and can not be supplemented to be, and thus it is not a SIDE of the shape, but rather a line that happens to fit MOST definitions of the other three lines that make up the SIDES. A triangle has three SIDES, and also coincidentally four lines that share a distinct relationship on the geometric consequences of the structure of the triangle.

Now with the fourth line properly distinguished as unique but close in definition to the other three; since its arbitrary endpoints suggest it is not structurally integral to the shape and must be drawn AFTER the structure of the shape is already defined, does that make the fourth line drawn here representative of time? The fourth line's relationship with the other three is a consequence, though, not a motive.

Party pooper mathematician here to answer the question. No, the triangle doesn't have 4 sides.

If a poligon is the closed circuit formed by straight lines, then the sides are those lines that follow the circuit.

By definition, this 4th line isn't a side. Just because It verifies some properties that the sides verify doesn't mean that it is one.

For example, phi is an irrational number. Pi and e are as well. They verify certain properties, but while pi and e are transcendental, phi is constructible.

Id you define "sides" a diferent way in which this line falls into, then it is a side. But a triangle is a three-angled polygon, and the only posibility to have a "closed" three-angled polygon (redundant) is to have three sides.

Party pooper mathematician signing off.

@vsauce - Wait, don't they have actually at least ten sides?

You can imagine triangle as a type of prism, with height of zero and three sided base. You can assume prism height is zero, therefore area of its three sides is also zero - but you can assume those sides are still there, just with zero height, zero area, and the whole prism has zero volume.

Then, the second base (the top) of the prism is another three sided base - so we already have five sides.

Now, imagine that prism is hollow - then each "out"side has other side in the "in"side - so you have ten sides total.

Ok I think I actually understood what is being said so I'll break it down.
Basically there are 3 circles that can be drawn relative to a triangle (in circle, 9 point circle, circumcircle). For each circle the 3 lines in the triangle has a property relative to the circle (each line will always have an end point on the circumference of the circumcircle, a midpoint on the circumference of the 9 point circle, and each line is tangential to the in circle).

Basically what Michael is saying is that it's possible to draw another line that fits all 3 of these properties (the orange line shown in the video). The line isn't literally the fourth line of the triangle, it just has all the same properties as the 3 lines of the triangle.

Realistically it's not as impressive as it seems because the line isn't a part of the triangle so it can be as long as needed, making the circumcircle property (endpoints) basically a given. After that all that is needed is to draw a tangential line to the in circle that also happens to have its midpoint on the 9 point circle.
